Chip Dunning wrote:
> There is one thing that I never quite got the lightbulb on in the desire 
> to make all things public or an interface. What if I have a class that 
> has a small section of code that is repeated constantly in the class. 
> The way I was taught back in the day was to pull that section code out 
> and make it a private member to enhance code readability and security 
> (singular updates).

...and that's all great, but that was before JUnit. Since then, we now 
have two opposing forces: the desire to protect code from being used 
unexpectedly (by making it private) and the desire to write JUnit tests 
that do not /overly/ depend on a class's implementation details.

Making code non-public has never made my life easier, so I don't see the 
point in doing it. If it weren't for Eclipse, I would never do it.

<opinion>
If it's important enough to test, then it's important enough to use, so 
make it public.
</opinion>
